Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Next-Generation Ion Mobility-Mass-Spectrometry of Protein-ligand and Multiprotein Complexes
Award.AbstractNarration:
With support from the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program in the Division of Chemistry and co-fund from the Molecular Biophysics program in the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences, Professor Brandon Ruotolo and his group at the University of Michigan will develop a nano-electrospray ionization (nESI) combined with ion mobility-mass spectrometry (IM-MS) technique as a key analytical tool for ascertaining the global structural consequences of drug molecule binding within multiprotein complexes. This unconventional approach will start by removing the water surrounding native-state multiprotein/drug complexes, it will then imbue these desolvated proteins with ionic charge, and then subsequently sort these protein complex ions according to both their size/shape and their mass in the gas phase. Developing nESI-IM-MS so that detailed information on drug/protein interactions can be obtained requires 1) a deeper physical understanding of how desolvated proteins can change their shape and structure (e.g. through protein unfolding) when given excess thermal energy in a vacuum and 2) the invention of robust protocols that use such internal temperature-induced protein/drug complex unfolding as a means of rapidly screening for new multiprotein inhibitors.

The intellectual merits of the proposed research primarily include the development of the new analytical tools described above, combined with a deeper chemical-physics type description of the protein unfolding processes operative in the absence of bulk solvent. Given the general importance of multiprotein complexes we expect that our work will be generally impactful, but we expect especially high impact within both the IM-MS and protein structure communities. The broader impacts of the proposed research include (a) the highly interdisciplinary training of participating graduate and undergraduate students in state-of-the-art IM-MS instrumentation, protein purification, protein-ligand screening, unimolecular reaction dynamics, gas-phase kinetics, and protein folding/structure. (b) The inclusion of students from historically underrepresented groups, in part through an NSF-funded REU program. (c) Developing an enhanced mass spectrometry curriculum at the University of Michigan, including novel laboratory exercises and instrumentation designed for undergraduate education, as well as a modular lecture course designed for graduate students. (d) Outreach to high school students through the Michigan Math and Science Scholars program at the University of Michigan.

Institution.Name: Regents of the University of Michigan - Ann Arbor
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN

POR.DRECONTENT:
Proteins comprise the machinery of life, often working in concert with other biological molecules in order to carry out a host of key cellular tasks.  In many cases, large interacting webs of proteins, having intact weights in the megadalton range, carry out essential life functions that remain mechanistically opaque.  Our understanding of protein function is tied in large part to our ability to assay the structures and stabilities of the large multi-protein complexes, but current tools capable of extracting such information are labor intensive and typically require large amounts of purified protein, dramatically limiting our ability to extract protein structure information from native-like mixtures.  This project was aimed at building new tools for the rapid assessment of such protein structure and stability information from mixtures.  The direct outputs of this project have taken the form of both new analytical methods, as well as novel pieces of software, now widely used in the broader scientific community. 

 

The broader impacts of this project included elements associated with student training, education and outreach.  In the context of student training, this project directly supported four chemistry graduate students six chemistry undergraduate students over its lifetime.  These students have now moved into the scientific workforce, pursuing careers in both academia and industry.  This project supported the early-stage development of new laboratory exercises for students, aimed at teaching sophomore/junior level undergraduates the tenants of cutting-edge protein structure methods being developed as part of our research program.  Two such laboratory exercises were constructed and piloted as part of this project, and are on-track toward incorporation into our standard chemistry curriculum. Finally, this project supported a range of outreach efforts associated with early-stage science education.  Specifically, project team members developed puzzle-based activities, based on the data analysis formalisms associated with our cutting-edge research projects, aimed at elementary school students.  Project team members also had the opportunity to travel to Nepal for scientific outreach activities aimed at high school students.

 


Last Modified: 01/30/2020
Modified by: Brandon Ruotolo

In many cases, large interacting webs of proteins, having intact weights in the megadalton range, carry out essential life functions that remain mechanistically opaque. Our understanding of protein function is tied in large part to our ability to assay the structures and stabilities of the large multi-protein complexes, but current tools capable of extracting such information are labor intensive and typically require large amounts of purified protein, dramatically limiting our ability to extract protein structure information from native-like mixtures. This project was aimed at building new tools for the rapid assessment of such protein structure and stability information from mixtures. The direct outputs of this project have taken the form of both new analytical methods, as well as novel pieces of software, now widely used in the broader scientific community. The broader impacts of this project included elements associated with student training, education and outreach. In the context of student training, this project directly supported four chemistry graduate students six chemistry undergraduate students over its lifetime. These students have now moved into the scientific workforce, pursuing careers in both academia and industry. This project supported the early-stage development of new laboratory exercises for students, aimed at teaching sophomore/junior level undergraduates the tenants of cutting-edge protein structure methods being developed as part of our research program. Two such laboratory exercises were constructed and piloted as part of this project, and are on-track toward incorporation into our standard chemistry curriculum. Specifically, project team members developed puzzle-based activities, based on the data analysis formalisms associated with our cutting-edge research projects, aimed at elementary school students.
